channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: California Supreme Court hears suit on public pension law aimed at saving billions
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Can California cut public pensions? The state Supreme Court is weighing a law designed to help reduce a shortfall of hundreds of billions of dollars.
item.content:encoded: Can California cut public pensions? The state Supreme Court is weighing a law designed to help reduce a shortfall of hundreds of billions of dollars.

media:content.media:description: The California Supreme Court is reviewing written arguments in a pension case that has attracted national attention.

item.title: Newsom calls reopening Yuba and Sutter counties a 'big mistake' amid coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna
item.description: Sutter and Yuba counties allowed businesses to reopen on Monday amid the coronavirus crisis after a similar decision was made in Modoc County in California's northeastern corner.
item.content:encoded: Sutter and Yuba counties allowed businesses to reopen on Monday amid the coronavirus crisis after a similar decision was made in Modoc County in California's northeastern corner.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

item.title: San Diego Marine recruits, SEALs resume training
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dyer
item.description: Though a few recruits tested positive for COVID-19, Marine commanding general says quarantine a success
item.content:encoded: Though a few recruits tested positive for COVID-19, Marine commanding general says quarantine a success

media:content.media:description: New recruits with Echo Company, 2nd Recruit Training Battalion, respond to orders during receiving at Marine Corps Recruit Depot, San Diego, May 4, 2020. Echo Company arrived at the depot three weeks ago and have been quarantined at a San Diego hotel since.

item.title: LAPD officer charged with shooting a fellow cop on camping trip
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Cindy Chang
item.description: San Bernardino County prosecutors say LAPD Officer Ismael Tamayo shot and wounded another off-duty officer over the weekend during a camping trip.
item.content:encoded: San Bernardino County prosecutors say LAPD Officer Ismael Tamayo shot and wounded another off-duty officer over the weekend during a camping trip.

media:content.media:description: Officer Ismael Tamayo, a 13-year-veteran of the LAPD, was booked by the county sheriff's department in connection with the 1 a.m. shooting at the Stoddard Wells Off-Highway Vehicle Area, Los Angeles police said in a statement.

item.title: California allows more Orange County beaches to reopen
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Priscella Vega, Phil Willon
item.description: Plans submitted by Dana Point, Huntington Beach and Seal Beach to allow the public to immediately access to the coastline were approved by Sacramento.
item.content:encoded: Plans submitted by Dana Point, Huntington Beach and Seal Beach to allow the public to immediately access to the coastline were approved by Sacramento.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Protesters wave flags along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Video of violent LAPD arrest in Boyle Heights sparks outrage, internal review
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Kevin Rector
item.description: Footage of an L.A. police officer repeatedly punching a man who appears to be unarmed and surrendering in Boyle Heights draws a furious response online.
item.content:encoded: Footage of an L.A. police officer repeatedly punching a man who appears to be unarmed and surrendering in Boyle Heights draws a furious response online.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA JANUARY 7, 2015 -- An LAPD cruiser sits parked at Hollywood and Highland near the scene of a shooting early Wednesday, January 7, 2015, in which authorities said a man stood on a sidewalk and began randomly firing into the air. The incident occurred about 2 a.m. on Hollywood Boulevard off Cosmo Street, said Sgt. Chad Lewis of the LAPD's Hollywood division. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California DMV offices could reopen this month, but with coronavirus changes

media:content.media:description: The California Department of Motor Vehicles said that it was alerted to "a potential security issue within its credit card processing services" but that there was no direct evidence its computer system had been breached. Above, a DMV office in Los Angeles in 2012.

media:content.media:description: MALIBU, CA - APRIL 23: A couple walk on Broad Beach on Thursday, April 23, 2020 in Malibu, CA. To fend off coronavirus contagion, Los Angeles County has kept beaches closed, but hundreds of beachgoers flaunted the rules up and down the coastline from Santa Monica to Malibu. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 6th Terminal Island prisoner dies of COVID-19; congresswoman says Fauci 'a little alarmed'
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: A sixth inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison in Los Angeles died over the weekend after testing positive for the coronavirus infection.
item.content:encoded: A sixth inmate at the Terminal Island federal prison in Los Angeles died over the weekend after testing positive for the coronavirus infection.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. APRIL 29, 2020 -- Exterior view of the Federal Correctional Institution Terminal Island in San Pedro. Nearly half of the inmates at the federal prison at Terminal Island in San Pedro have tested positive for the coronavirus in what had has become the nation's worst outbreak in a federal penitentiary. As of Tuesday, 443 of the prison's 1,055 inmates have the virus, along with 10 staff members. Two inmates have already died of complications related to COVID-19, according to the Bureau of Prisons. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Voices from the spectrum: Autistic people deal with the coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Autistic people have diverse experiences that resist easy generalization. But in recent interviews, a number of autistic adults say that many are practiced in dealing with the challenges.
item.content:encoded: Autistic people have diverse experiences that resist easy generalization. But in recent interviews, a number of autistic adults say that many are practiced in dealing with the challenges.

media:content.media:description: CHATSWORTH, CA - APRIL 28: Hector Ramirez poses for a portrait outside his home on Tuesday, April 28, 2020 in Chatsworth, CA. Ramirez is autistic, and COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted his daily routine. He says that he has been using coping mechanisms to help him deal with his isolation. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rotting food. Hungry masses. Chaotic supply chains. Coronavirus upends the U.S. food system

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA -- APRIL 28: Associates fill orders for both Ralphs and Food 4 Less grocery stores at the Ralphs Distribution Center on Tuesday, April 28, 2020, in Riverside, CA. The 80 acre, 1.2 million square feet, full service distribution center employing 1100 workers took on more product after automated warehouses couldn't keep up with the spike in demand after restaurants were shuttered. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 29: Pedestrians wearing PPE ride the Westbound 33 Bus towards Venice in downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, April 29, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. For thousands of Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus drivers, going to work during a pandemic means spending hours in a confined space with strangers, wondering whether this will be the day they get sick. Ridership on Los Angeles County buses has fallen 65% since the pandemic started. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening would start slow, not be complete for a year or longer, expert estimates

item.title: 'The fight is always somewhere in us': Asian American history and a Little Tokyo combo meal
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong

item.content:encoded: The revival of Tokyo Gardens' classic chashu shumai has been a much-needed bright spot during the pandemic — and a reminder of the resiliency of L.A.'s Asian American community.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 1, 2020. Chef Glen Ishii makes chashu shumai, which is a heritage item that Ishii's grandmother made at the family restaurant in the 1940s. Glen Ishii is a third generation chef who owns and operates Jist Cafe and is helping to provide meals to Little Tokyo residents and senior citizens with takeout and deivery food during the coronavirus pandemic. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'My long goodbye': Already coping with her husband's Alzheimer's, a wife now faces coronavirus lockouts
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber

item.content:encoded: For Felice Blair, the quarantine has compounded the feelings of guilt and helplessness that sometimes come with moving a loved one into a nursing home.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - APRIL 29: Felice Blair poses for a portrait outside of her home on Wednesday, April 29, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. Blair's husband, Bernard, 77, has Alzheimer's and lives in a skilled nursing facility; since the coronavirus lockdown, she hasn't been able to visit him and during that time, her birthday, his birthday and their anniversary all have passed. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

Chavez Blvd. and Soto St. has slow down as California officials extended stay-at-home orders into May and residents entered Easter weekend with unprecedented limits on their movements. item.content:encoded: California's rural areas are in revolt against Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide coronavirus rules, which make little sense in burgs such as Bieber.

media:content.media:description: State Sen. Jim Nielsen, R-Tehama, left discusses the impact the coronavirus is having on rural residents and businesses during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, April 28, 2020. Representatives of six north state counties are calling on Gov. Gavin Newsom to allow them to exercise local authority to implement a careful and phased reopening of the local economies. Nielsen was accompanied by Yuba City restaurant owners Sharlene Katz, of the Dancing Tomato Caffe, second from left and Chris and Sandee Drown of the Happy Viking restaurant. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases top 25,000, with more than 1,200 deaths
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials have reported 781 new cases of the coronavirus and 21 additional related deaths.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials have reported 781 new cases of the coronavirus and 21 additional related deaths.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

media:content.media:description: MARIPOSA, CA - APRIL 30, 2020 - - Matthew Matthiessen, CEO of John C. Fremont Hospital, has his temperature read while being screened by EMT Doug Michael in Mariposa on April 30, 2020. All employees at the hospital have to be screened for symptom of COVID-19 and are asked questions if they have any symptoms from the virus before they are allowed to go to work. Mariposa County is one of five California counties that as of April 28 only had one reported coronavirus case, despite the fact all the surroundings have. More than 47,000 Californians have tested positive for the novel coronavirus but in Mariposa County, Tuesday's result was the first. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fear, uncertainty, exhaustion: One doctor's shift in the UCLA emergency room
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.
item.content:encoded: An ER doctor promises a COVID-19 patient tests, a bed, oxygen and wishes she could do more.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 06: Dr. Lisa Dabby, 41, an emergency room physician with UCLA Medical Center in Santa Monica is assisted by Sr. emergency trauma technician Jorge Velasco in the donning of a PAPR (powered air-purifying respirator) in the emergency room where they are on the front line of the coronavirus COVID-19 outbreak. During a typical 10-hour shift, she treats appendicitis, overdoses, skateboard accidents, arrhythmia, the usual off-the-street accidents, illnesses and conditions that flare up without notice. With more than 10 years at the hospital, she knows what to expect and how to treat it, but the coronavirus has changed that. She treats about 20 patients a day who arrive with coughs, fevers, shortness of breath and the fear and uncertainty that this pandemic has brought.UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Will Orange County enforce Newsom beach closure? Officials vow a fight
item.dc:creator: Anh Do, Hannah Fry, Richard Winton
item.description: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.
item.content:encoded: Huntington Beach and Dana Point have voted to seek injunctions, and the Orange County sheriff has said he doesn't plan to arrest beachgoers.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- THURSDAY, APRIL 30, 2020: Kids do flips off the lifeguard tower while others relax on the sand on the last day of open beaches in Huntington Beach after Gov. Newsom announced the "hard close" of all Orange County state and local beaches Thursday, April 30, 2020. Newsom's retaliation came after thousands of Californians flocked to the shoreline there over the weekend in defiance of a statewide stay-at-home order enacted to stem the spread of the coronavirus. "When you contact the police chiefs to enforce your will as a leader-in my book you establish a police state" said Huntington Beach resident Pete Hamborg. "It's a moment that Gavin Newsom is taking away from us and are the very moments that empower us to deal with this crisis on a day-to-day basis." "I think the beach, which belongs to all Californians, is critical to our emotional health and well-being." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times
